surface.zone:
effect that of these books had upon me
produced
. They pro
duced in me an infinity of new images & ideas
that sometimes raised me to extacy but oftenor more
frequently
sunk me to the lowest dejection. In the
Sorrows of Werter besides the interrest of its
simple and affecting story so many opinions are
canvassed and so many lights thrown upon what
had
^
hitherto been
to me hitherto
dark obscure subects that I found
^
in it
a never end source of speculation. & astonishment. The
gentle and domestic manners it described com
bined with lofty sentiments, and feelings
^
which had for their object something out of self
accor
ded well with my experience among my pro
tectors.
^
and with the wants which were for ever alive within my own bosom.
But I thought Werter himself a more
divine being than I had ever beheld,
or imagined. His cha
racter contained no pretention but it sunk
deep – for he thought The disquisitions upon death
and suicide gave were calculated to fill me
with astonishment wonder. – I did not pretend to
enter into the merits of the case yet I
i nclined towards the opinion of the Hero
whose extinction I wept although I did without
precisely
not
understanding it. As I read however I
applied much
^
personally to my self
^
and own feelings & condition I found my
self at the same tim e similar yet
^
at the same time
strangely unlike the beings concerning whom
I read and who were my
to whose conver
sation I was a listener – I sympathized
I pa with & partly understood them– but
I was unformed in mind. I was dependant
on none, & related to none – "The path of my
departure was free"! and there was none
to lament my extinction my annihilation – My person
was hideous and my stature gigantic – What
did this mean? Who was I? What was I?

surface.zone:
Whence
did I come?
What was
my destination? these questions continually recurred but I
was unable to solve them
The volume of Plutarchs lives which I
possessed contained the histories of the first
founders of the ancient republics– This book
had a far different effect upon me from
the letters Sorrows the letters of Werter. I learned
from that
his Werter's imaginations despondency & gloom; but Plutarch
taught me high thoughts—he elevated me above
m the wretched sphere of my own reflections
to admire & love the heroes of past ages. Yet
Many things I read surpassed my unterstanding
and knowledge
^
experience I had a very t confused know
ledge of kingdoms & wide extents of country
mighty rivers and boundless seas. But I
was perfectly unacquainted with towns &
large assemblegs assemblages of men. The cottage
were of my protectors was
had been
was
the o only school in
where which
I had studied human
nature — But this book threw a new light upon
^
developed new & mightier scenes of action
it I read of men concerned in public
affairs governing their species — an or masser
cering their speceis. I felt the greatest ardour
for virtue rise within me and abhor
rence for vice
as far as I understood it the
signification of those terms relative as they
were only, as I applied them, to pleasure
and pain
^
alone. . with Induced by these feelings it may be
I was of course led to admire peacable
lawgivers Numa, Solon & Lycurgus more than
Romulus and Theseus. The patriarchal lives
of my protectors induced caused
to a greater degree
these impressions
^
to take a firm hold on my mind — perhaps if my first resid
ence
human
introduction to
intercourse
with
humanity
had been
^
with made by a young soldier burning

surface.zone:
contented & happy. Such were their fee
lings
^
were serene & peaceful, while
mine became every day more
unhappy
miserable
– encrease of knowledge only shewed
discovered to
me more plainly
^
clearly what a wretched outcast
I was. I cherished hope it is true but
it vanished when I beheld my person re
flected
in the water or even my shadow
in the moonshine —I endeavoured to hush
crush
these fears and to fortify myself for the
trial which in a few months I resolved
to undergo; and sometimes I allowed my
thoughts unchecked by reason to ramble
in the fields of Paradise &
fan dared
to fancy amiable & lovely beings sym
pathizing with my feelings and cheeri
ng my d gloom — Their angelic cont
countenances breathed smiles of consola
tion — But it was all a dream – No
Eve waited on soothed my sorrows
or shared my thoughts. I was alone.
I remembered Adams supplication to
his creator but where was mine?
He had abbandoned me and in the
bitterness of my heart I cursed him.
Autumn passed thus and
with
surpise & grief I saw the leaves decay
& fall,
And nature again assume
the barren & bleak appearance
it had when I first beheld the
woods and the lovely moon. I
did not heed the cold bleakness of the weather
By my consti
tution
I was more fitted for that this sufferance
of cold
than heat. But my only joys were

joys depending on

known and loved

surface.zone:
Chap. 7 th
The season winter advanced and it was now about a and an entire revolution of the
year
^
seasons had taken place since I awoke into life.– and I then at
that time My attention
^
at this time was now solely
directed towards my plan of introducing
myself into the cottage of my protectors. I revol
ved many projects but that on which I
finally fixed was to enter their dwelling when
the blind old man was should be alone. My voice
although harsh had nothin
g terrible in
it. and I had sagacity enough to discover
that the unnatural hideousness of my person
was the chief object of horror am with those
who had formerly beheld me:–my voice al
though harsh, had nothing terrible in
it. I thought therefore that if in the absence
of his children I could gain the goodwill
of the old De Lacey I might by his means be
tolerated by the my younger protectors.
One clear One day when the sun
shone on the red leaves that strewed
the ground, and all diffused cheerfulness
although it denied warmth Maimouna Safie
Agatha and Felix set out on a long country
walk and the old man at his own desire
was left alone in the cottage. When his chil
dren had departed he took up his guitar &
played ver several mournful but sweet
airs:
that I had seldom
^
more sweet & mournful that I had ever heard him play
before. At first his countenance was illumi
nated with pleasure but as he continued thought
fullness and sadness succeeded and laying down

surface.zone:
the instrument he sat absorbed
in reflection.
My heart beat quick. This
was the hour & moment of trial
which was to
^
would decide my fea hopes
or
I quitted my hovel with trem The
servants of the cottage were gone
to a neighbouring fair:– All was
silent in and around the cottage
It was an excellent opportunity
yet when I rose proceeded to execute my plan
my limbs failed me, and I sunk
to the ground. Again I rose and
with with
exerting
all of the firm
n ess
^
of which I
was master of removed the planks
which I had placed before my
hovel to conceal my retreat – The
fresh air revived me and with
renewed determination I approach
ed the door of the cottage. I knock
ed – "who is there?" said the old
man– "come in"— I entered – "Pardon
this intrusion" said I– "I am a
traveller, in want of a little
rest. and you would greatly oblige
me if you would allow me to
remain a few minutes before
your fire." "Enter" said De Lacey &
I will try in what manner I can re
lieve your wants– but unfortunately
my children are out from home, and
^
as I am blind
I am afraid therefore I shall find it
difficult to procure food for you"–

which I had placed before my
hovel to conceal my retreat – The
fresh air revived me and with
renewed determination I approach
ed the door of the cottage. I knock
ed – "who is there?" said the old
man– "come in"— I entered – "Pardon
this intrusion" said I– "I am a
traveller, in want of a little
rest. and you would greatly oblige
me if you would allow me to
remain a few minutes before
your fire." "Enter" said De Lacey &
I will try in what manner I can re
lieve your wants– but unfortunately
my children are out from home, and
^
as I am blind
I am afraid therefore I shall find it
difficult to procure food for you"–
xml.del: I quitted my hovel with trem

surface.zone:
"Do not trouble yourself, my kind
host," I replied, I have food, it is warmth
and rest only that I need.–I sat down
and a silence ensued; I kn
e w very
well that every minute was precious
to me yet I remained irresolute
^
in what
to say
manner to
comemmence
the interview
when the old man began
^
addressed me –"By
your language St
^
r anger, I suppose you
are my countryman, are you french?"
"No," replied I but I was educated by a
french family and understand that
language only. I am unfortunate and
a Str I am now going to claim the
protection of some friends, whom I sincerely
love but and of whose favour I have
some hopes." "Are these Germans"–
Asked
De Lacey – know"No –They are french –But let
us change the subject –I am an unfortu
nate & deserted creature. I look around and
I have no relation or friend
^
on earth – The se kind
^
amiable
people to whom I go, have never seem
me and know little of me. I am full
of fears, for if I fail there, I am an
outcast in the world for ever."
Do not despair, said the old man.
To be friendless is indeed to be unfortu
nate : but
^
the hearts of men are when unpre
judiced by obvious self interrest, are full
of brotherly love and charity. Rely therefore
on your hopes and if these dispositions
of your friends are kind these friends
are good and amiable – do not fear despair for your

the interview

surface.zone:
They are kind– I answered– They are the most
amiable excellent
creatures in the world but unfortu
nately they are prejudiced against me. I
have good dispositions –I love virtue and
detest knowledge, –my life has been hitherto
harmless & in some degree beneficial
but a fatal prejudice clouds their eyes
and where they ought to see a feeling
and kind friend, they behold only a detes
table monster.–
That is indeed unfortunate, replied
De Lacey– but if you are really blameless can
not you undeceive them?
This is That is
the task that
what I
shall
goin
^
am about
endeavouring
to undertake
that task — said I "And it is on that
account that I feel so many overwhelming
terrors—I love these friends tenderly; for many
months I have
^
for many months
unknown to them been
for many months in the habits of daily kindness towards them,
but they believe that I wish to injure
them and it is that prejudice which
I wish to over come.
Where do these friends reside, said de
Lacey — N
Near here. I replied
^
on this spot.
[
The old man
paused a moment and then continued
If you will unreservedly confide to me
the particulars I perhaps may be of use
in undeceiving them. I am blind and
cannot judge of your countenance but
there is somthing in your words that which
persuades me that you are sincere.

surface.zone:
I am poor and an exile, but it
will afford me true pleasure to of be
in any way serviceable to a fellow human creature.—
Excellent man – exclaimed I, I
thank you and accept your
^
generous offer
X
X You raise me
from the dust
by this kindess and
I trust now that I shall not be driven
from the society & sympathy of my
fellow creatures
Heaven forbid! even if you are were really
criminal for that not in can only drive you
to desperation and not reform
^
instigate you
^
to virtue —
I also am unfortunate.– I
and my
family have been condemned when
although innocent judge therefore
if I do not sympath feel for your
misfortunes—
How can I thank you, my best &
only benefactor – from your lips first
have I heard the voice of kindness
directed towards me –I shall be for
ever grateful and your present
humanity assures me of success with
the friends whom I am on the
point of meeting
May I know the names of and residence
of those friends? asked De Lacey.
I paused — This was the moment
of decision which was to rob me
^
of or
bestow happiness
^
on me for ever – I sum
I struggled vainly to find for firmness
sufficient
enough to answer him – but the effort
destroyed all my remaining strentgth
& I sank on the a chair & sobbed aloud

surface.zone:
At that moment I heard the steps
of my younger protectors—I had not
a moment to lose, but seizing the
hand of the old man I cried– Now
is the time, save and protect me
You and your family are the
friends whom I seek – Do not you
des
^
e rt me in the hour of trial
! .–
Great God! exclaimed the old
man – Who are you?
At that instan
t the cottage
door opened and Felix, Maimouna
Safie
and Agatha entered – Who can
describe their horro
r and asto
nishment on beholding
^
me –Agatha
fainted & Maimouna Safie unable
to attend to her friend rushed
out of the cottage.– Felix darted
forward and with supernatural
strength tore me from his father
to whose knees I clung –In a
transport of fury he dashed
me to the ground and struck
me voilenlently with a stick
I saw him going to on the point
of repeating the p blow when
overcome by pain and anguish
I quitted the cottage and in the
general tumult, escaped unper
ceived to my hovel.
